titleStmt.title: SII 3.23: original edition by Eugen Julius Theodor Hultzsch
No. 23.—ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE SECOND PRAKARA, RIGHT OF ENTRANCE.

summary.p: This inscription is dated in the 23rd year of the reign of Tribhuvanachakravartin Kulōttuṅga-Chōḷadēva, who claims to have conquered Īḻam (Ceylon), Madurai (Madhurā) and Karuvūr and to have cut off the head of the Pāṇḍya king. The time of this Kulōttuṅga-Chōḷa is settled by an inscription in the Raṅganāyaka temple at Nellūr (Nellore), which couples Śaka-Saṁvat 1119 with the 19th year of his reign.No. 197 of 1894; Ep. Ind. Vol. IV. p. 219. On the basis of this inscription and of some others which contain elements for astronomical calculation, Professor Kielhorn has shown that the king's reign commenced between the 5th June and 8th July, A.D. 1178.Ibid. p. 266. Kulōttuṅga-Chōḷadēva I. ascended the throne in A.D. 1070,See Professor Kielhorn's calculations, l.c. and Kulōttuṅga-Chōḷadēva II. issued the Chellūr plates in A.D. 1132.Ind. Ant. Vol. XX. p. 285. Consequently, the king, to whose reign the present inscription belongs, has to be designated Kulōttuṅga-Chōḷadēva III. In other inscriptions he bears the names Parakēsarivarman, Vīrarājēndradēva (II.) and Tribhuvanavīradēva. His latest date is the 39th year in an unpublished inscription at Chidambaram. Accordingly, he must have been the immediate predecessor of Tribhuvanachakravartin Rājarājadēva, who ascended the throne about A.D. 1216.See Vol. I. p. 86. An inscription of the 2nd year of Tribhuvanachakravartin Rājarājadēva at Tiruviḍaimarudūr (No. 143 of 1895) mentions an image which had been set up in the 37th year of “the great king (periya-dēvar) Tribhuvanavīradēva.”

The immediate purpose of the subjoined inscription is to record that the king granted to the Karuvūr temple the village of Maṉṉaṟai and a portion of KēraḷapaḷḷiThe same village is mentioned in a short inscription (No. 68 of 1890) of the 34th year of Parāntaka I. at Sōmūr near Karavūr. in Taṭṭaiyūr-nāḍu.

(Line 1.) Hail ! Prosperity ! In the twenty-third year (of the reign) of the emperor of the three worlds, Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōḻadēva, who was pleased to take Īḻam, Madurai, the crowned head of the Pāṇḍya, and Karuvūr,—the emperor of the three worlds, Kōnēri[ṉmai] koṇḍāṉ,Regarding this title see Vol. II. pp. 110 and 246. (addresses the following order) to the Pūjāri (dēvarkaṉmi), to the overseers of the Śrī-Māhēśvaras, and to the manager of the temple of Tiruvānilai-Mahādēva at Karuvūr, alias Muḍivaḻaṅgu-Śōḻapuram, (a city) in Veṅgālanāḍu, (a district) of Koṅgu, alias Śōḻa-Kēraḷa-maṇḍalam.

(L. 3.) “We have given as temple land to (the god) Mahādēva of the Tiruvānilai (temple) for the expenses required by this god (the village of) Maṉṉaṟai, containing fifty vēli of land in Kēra[ḷa]paḷḷi and in Maṉṉaṟai in Taṭṭaiyūr-nāḍu, (a district) of the same nāḍu.This refers apparently to Veṅgāla-nāḍu in l. 2. But No. 24, l. 3, shows that both Veṅgāla-nāḍu and Taṭṭaiyūr-nāḍu were independent districts of Śōḻa-Kēraḷa-maṇḍalam.

(L. 4.) “Having declared that the land enclosed within the four great boundaries of this village, (including) the grass for the calves, and (the land) enjoyed in full by the great village, should be given to this god as tax-free temple land from the twenty-third (year of our reign), we have ordered (our) revenue officersvarikku kūṟu ceyvārkaḷ (which occurs also in Vol. II. No. 21, second section, l. 4) corresponds to variyilār in No. 20, l. 21. to enter (it) as such in the account (book).”

(L. 6.) “If this land is (actually) taken possession of, you shall permit (the temple authorities) to take possession (of it) as tax-free temple land and to defray the expenses (of the temple) from (the produce of) these villages from the twenty-third (year of our reign), as determined by Kēraḷaṉ.”This is perhaps the name of the person at whose instance the king made the grant.

(L. 7.) Written by the royal secretary, Mīṉavaṉ-Mūvēndavēḷāṉ. This (is) the writing of Toṇḍaimāṉ. This (is) the writing of Viḻiñattarayaṉ. This (is) the writing of Varaguṇarājaṉ. This (is) the writing of Paṅgaḷattarayaṉ. This (is) the writing of Vāḷuvarājaṉ.
